{{Infobox number | number = 190 }} '''190''' ('''one hundred [and] ninety''') is the [[natural number]] following [[189 (number)|189]] and preceding [[191 (number)|191]].
==In mathematics== * 190 is an [[even number]] * 190 is a [[deficient number]], as the sum of its [[Divisor#Further notions and facts|proper divisor]]s (170) is less than 190 * 190 is a [[happy number]] * 190 is a [[Harshad number]] or Niven number divisible by the [[Digit sum|sum of its digits]] * 190 is a [[sphenic number]] * 190 is a [[Square-free integer|square free number]] * 190 is a [[triangular number]] * 190 is a [[hexagonal number]] * 190 is a [[centered nonagonal number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A060544|title=Sloane's A060544 : Centered 9-gonal (also known as nonagonal or enneagonal) numbers|last=|first=|date=|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-05-28}}</ref> * 190 is a 33-[[Polygonal number|gonal number]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oeis.org/A098923|title=Sloane's A098923 : 33-gonal numbers|last=|first=|date=|website=The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences|publisher=OEIS Foundation|access-date=2016-05-28}}</ref>
==In other fields== ''' 190''' is also: * [[Everclear (alcohol)|Everclear]] [[neutral grain spirit]] is available at 190 or 151 [[Alcoholic proof|proof]] * 1-9-0 [[emergency telephone number]] in [[Brazil]]
==See also== * [[190s]] * [[List of highways numbered 190]] * [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 190]] * [[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 190|United States Supreme Court cases, Volume 190]] * [[S-130/S-190 training courses]] * [[Goznak#190th Anniversary|Goznak 190th Anniversary]] * [[Mercedes-Benz 190 (disambiguation)]] *[[Focke-Wulf Fw 190|Fw 190]]

'''Alhazen's problem''' is a problem in [[geometrical optics]] first formulated by [[Ptolemy]] in 150 AD.<ref name=Weiss>{{cite web | last=Weisstein | first=Eric | title=Alhazen's Billiard Problem | publisher=[[Mathworld]] | url=http://mathworld.wolfram.com/AlhazensBilliardProblem.html | accessdate=2008-09-24}}</ref> It is named for the 11th-century Arab mathematician [[Alhazen]] (''Ibn al-Haytham'') who presented a geometric solution in his ''[[Book of Optics]]''. The algebraic solution involves [[quartic equation]]s and was found only as late as 1965, by Jack M. Elkin.
==Geometric formulation== {{see|Geometrical optics}} The problem comprises drawing lines from two points in a circle meeting at a third point on its [[circumference]] and making equal angles with the [[Surface normal|normal]] at that point. Thus, its main application in optics is to solve the problem, "Given a light source and a spherical mirror, find the point on the mirror where the light will be reflected to the eye of an observer." This leads to an [[Quartic equation|equation of the fourth degree]].<ref name=MacTutor>{{MacTutor|id=Al-Haytham|title=Abu Ali al-Hasan ibn al-Haytham}}</ref><ref name=Weiss/>
==Alhazen's solution== Ibn al-Haytham solved the problem using [[conic section]]s and a geometric proof. He derived a formula for the sum of fourth powers, where previously only the formulas for the sums of squares and cubes had been stated.
His method can be readily generalized to find the formula for the sum of any integral powers, although he did not himself do this (perhaps because he only needed the fourth power to calculate the volume of the paraboloid he was interested in). He used his result on sums of integral powers to perform what would now be called an [[Integral|integration]], where the formulas for the sums of integral squares and fourth powers allowed him to calculate the volume of a [[paraboloid]].<ref name=Katz>Victor J. Katz (1995), "Ideas of Calculus in Islam and India", ''Mathematics Magazine'''''68''' (3): 163–174 [165-9 & 173-4]</ref>
==Algebraic solution== Later mathematicians such as [[Christiaan Huygens]], [[James Gregory (mathematician)|James Gregory]], [[Guillaume de l'Hôpital]], [[Isaac Barrow]], and many others, attempted to find an algebraic solution to the problem, using various methods, including [[analytic geometry|analytic methods of geometry]] and derivation by [[complex number]]s.<ref name=Smith>{{cite journal | last1 = Smith | first1 = John D. | year = 1992 | title = The Remarkable Ibn al-Haytham | url = | journal = The Mathematical Gazette | volume = 76 | issue = 475| pages = 189–198 | doi=10.2307/3620392}}</ref>
An algebraic solution to the problem was finally found in 1965 by Jack M. Elkin, an actuarian.<ref>{{Citation|last=Elkin|first=Jack M.|title=A deceptively easy problem|journal=Mathematics Teacher|volume=58|issue=3|pages=194–199|year=1965|jstor=27968003}}</ref> Other solutions were discovered in 1989, by Harald Riede<ref>{{Citation|last=Riede|first=Harald|title=Reflexion am Kugelspiegel. Oder: das Problem des Alhazen|journal=Praxis der Mathematik|volume=31|issue=2|pages=65–70|year=1989|language=German}}</ref> and in 1997 by the [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] mathematician [[Peter M. Neumann]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Neumann|first=Peter M.|author-link=Peter M. Neumann|title=Reflections on Reflection in a Spherical Mirror|journal=[[American Mathematical Monthly]]|volume=105|issue=6|pages=523–528|year=1998|jstor=2589403|mr=1626185}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Highfield |first=Roger |date=1 April 1997 |title=Don solves the last puzzle left by ancient Greeks |journal=[[Electronic Telegraph]] |volume=676 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=/archive/1997/04/01/ngre01.html |accessdate=2008-09-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041123051228/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=%2Farchive%2F1997%2F04%2F01%2Fngre01.html |archivedate=November 23, 2004 }}</ref>
==Generalization== Recently, Mitsubishi Electric Research Labs researchers solved the extension of Alhazen's problem to general rotationally symmetric quadric mirrors including hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptical mirrors.<ref>{{Citation|last=Agrawal |first=Amit |last2=Taguchi |first2=Yuichi |last3=Ramalingam |first3=Srikumar |year=2011 |title=Beyond Alhazen's Problem: Analytical Projection Model for Non-Central Catadioptric Cameras with Quadric Mirrors |publisher=IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition |url=http://www.umiacs.umd.edu/~aagrawal/cvpr11/fp/fp.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307040949/http://www.umiacs.umd.edu/~aagrawal/cvpr11/fp/fp.html |archivedate=2012-03-07 }}</ref> They showed that the mirror reflection point can be computed by solving an eighth degree equation in the most general case. If the camera (eye) is placed on the axis of the mirror, the degree of the equation reduces to six.<ref name=AgrawalECCV10>{{Citation|last=Agrawal |first=Amit |last2=Taguchi |first2=Yuichi |last3=Ramalingam |first3=Srikumar |year=2010 |title=Analytical Forward Projection for Axial Non-Central Dioptric and Catadioptric Cameras |publisher=European Conference on Computer Vision |url=http://www.umiacs.umd.edu/~aagrawal/eccv10/fp/fp.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307042704/http://www.umiacs.umd.edu/~aagrawal/eccv10/fp/fp.html |archivedate=2012-03-07 }}</ref> Alhazen's problem can also be extended to multiple refractions from a spherical ball. Given a light source and a spherical ball of certain refractive index, the closest point on the spherical ball where the light is refracted to the eye of the observer can be obtained by solving a tenth degree equation.<ref name=AgrawalECCV10/>

J. Leek, M. Beck, A. Blais, T. Ihn, K. Ensslin, and A. '''Andreas Wallraff''' is a German [[physicist]] who conducts research in [[quantum information processing]] and [[quantum optics]]. He has taught as a professor at [[ETH Zürich]] in [[Zürich, Switzerland]] since 2006.<ref name="QuDevSite">{{cite web|url=https://qudev.ethz.ch/andreas_wallraff |title=Quantum Device Lab |date= |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> He worked as a research scientist with [[Robert J. Schoelkopf]] at [[Yale University]] from 2002 to 2005, during which time he performed experiments in which the coherent interaction of a single photon with a single quantum electronic circuit was observed for the first time.<ref name="Nature2004">A. Wallraff, D. I. Schuster, A. Blais, L. Frunzio, R.- S. Huang, J. Majer, S. Kumar, S. M. Girvin, and R. J. Schoelkopf, "Strong coupling of a single photon to a superconducting qubit using circuit quantum electrodynamics", ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' '''431''', 162-167 (2004), {{DOI|10.1038/nature02851}}</ref> His current work at ETH Zürich focuses on hybrid quantum systems combining [[superconducting]] [[electronic circuits]] with [[semiconductor]] [[quantum dots]] and individual [[Rydberg atoms]] as well as [[quantum error correction]] with [[superconducting qubits]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.qudev.ethz.ch/research%20topics |title=Quantum Device Lab Research Topics |date= |accessdate=2017-06-19}}</ref>
He has contributed primarily to the field of [[quantum information science]], particularly in [[superconducting quantum computing]] and hybrid quantum systems.<ref name="Tagesanzeiger2011">{{cite web|url=http://www.tagesanzeiger.ch/digital/computer/Auf-dem-Weg-zum-Schweizer-Supercomputer/story/25692897 |title=Auf dem Weg zum Schweizer Supercomputer |date=2011-06-28 |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref>
== Education and earlier work== Andreas Wallraff obtained his undergraduate degrees in physics from [[Imperial College London]] and [[RWTH Aachen University]] and conducted research on [[soliton]] dynamics in stacked [[superconductor-insulator-superconductor tunnel junction|Josephson tunnel junctions]] for his master's degree at the [[Forschungszentrum Jülich]] and RWTH Aachen, which he earned in 1997.<ref name="QuDevSite" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://qudev.phys.ethz.ch/content/science/thesis/dipl_wallraff.pdf |title=Fluxon Dynamics and Radiation Emission in Twofold Long Josephson Junction Stacks |date=1997-01-27 |accessdate=2017-06-15}}</ref><ref name="FIRSTprofile">{{cite web|url=http://www.first.ethz.ch/people/people-a-z/person-detail.html?persid=134453 |title=Wallraff, Andreas, Prof. Dr. |date= |accessdate=2017-07-06}}</ref> During his doctoral research on soliton and vortex dynamics in superconductors at the [[University of Erlangen-Nuremberg]], he observed for the first time the tunneling and energy level quantization of an individual [[quantum vortex]] for which he obtained a PhD degree in physics in 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://qudev.ethz.ch/content/science/thesis/dr_wallraff.pdf |title=Fluxon Dynamics in Annular Josephson Junctions: From Relativistic Strings to Quantum Particles |date=2000-07-18 |accessdate=2017-06-15}}</ref>
Following his doctoral research, Wallraff continued to work as a research scientist and later as an assistant professor at the University of Erlangen-Nuremberg.<ref name="FIRSTprofile" /> In 2002, he left Europe to work as a postdoctoral researcher with Robert J. Schoelkopf and [[Michel Devoret]] within the Department of Applied Physics at Yale University in [[New Haven, Connecticut]].<ref name="FIRSTprofile" /> During this time, he was an author on papers regarding the coupling of superconducting [[qubits]] via a [[microwave cavity|cavity]] [[Quantum bus|bus]] and the coherent interaction of a single photon to a [[Cooper-pair box]], among others.<ref name="Nature2004" /><ref>J. Majer, [[J. M. Chow]], J. M. Gambetta, J. Koch, B. R. Johnson, J. A. Schreier, L. Frunzio, D. I. Schuster, A. A. Houck, A. Wallraff, A. Blais, [[M. H. Devoret]], S. M. Girvin, and R. J. Schoelkopf, "Coupling superconducting qubits via a cavity bus", ''Nature'' '''449''', 443-447 (2007), {{DOI|10.1038/nature06184}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.photonics.com/Article.aspx?AID=30972|title=All Aboard the Quantum 'Bus'|accessdate=2017-08-07|date=2007-09-27}}</ref> In 2004 he was appointed as an associate research scientist in the Department of Applied Physics at Yale and in June 2005 he was elected as a tenure-track assistant professor at ETH Zürich.<ref name="FIRSTprofile" /> Following the professorship appointment, he departed from Yale and started the Quantum Device Lab at ETH Zürich in January 2006, encouraged by the freedom of research afforded to him by the university.<ref name="Tagesanzeiger2011" /> In 2011, he was chosen from among 380 ETH Zürich professors to be awarded the [[:de:Max Rössler|Max Rössler]] Prize for his research activities.<ref name="Tagesanzeiger2011" /> In 2012, he worked as a visiting professor at the [[Kastler-Brossel Laboratory]] within the [[École Normale Supérieure]] in [[Paris, France]].<ref name="QuDevSite" />
== Research topics == Wallraff has in recent years been studying a variety of topics related to quantum information science. Among them include interactions between distant [[Circuit_quantum_electrodynamics#Artificial_atoms.2C_Qubits|artificial atoms]],<ref>A. F. van Loo, A. Fedorov, K. Lalumière, B. C. Sanders, A. Blais, and Andreas Wallraff, "Photon-Mediated Interactions Between Distant Artificial Atoms", ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' '''342''', 6165, 1494-96 (2013), {{DOI|10.1126/science.1244324}}</ref> quantum [[many-body]] systems,<ref>C. Eichler, J. Mlynek, J. Butscher, P. Kurpiers, K. Hammerer, T. J. Osborne, and A. Wallraff, "Exploring Interacting Quantum Many-Body Systems by Experimentally Creating Continuous Matrix Product States in Superconducting Circuits", ''[[Physical Review X]]'' '''5''', 041044 (2015), {{DOI|10.1103/PhysRevX.5.041044}}</ref> digital [[quantum simulation]],<ref>Y. Salathé, M. Mondal, M. Oppliger, J. Heinsoo, P. Kurpiers, A. Potočnik, A. Mezzacapo, U. Las Heras, L. Lamata, E. Solano, S. Filipp, and A. Wallraff, "Digital Quantum Simulation of Spin Models with Circuit Quantum Electrodynamics", ''Physical Review X'' '''5''', 021027 (2015), {{DOI|10.1103/PhysRevX.5.021027}}</ref> [[quantum nonlocality]],<ref>M. Jerger, Y. Reshitnyk, M. Oppliger, A. Potočnik, M. Mondal, A. Wallraff, K. Goodenough, S. Wehner, K. Juliusson, N. K. Langford, and A. Fedorov, "Contextuality without nonlocality in a superconducting quantum system", ''[[Nature Communications]]'' '''7''', 12390 (2016), {{DOI|10.1038/ncomms12930}}</ref> the implementation of the [[Toffoli gate]] in quantum computation,<ref>A. Fedorov, L. Steffen, M. Baur, M. P. da Silva, and A. Wallraff, "Implementation of a Toffoli gate with superconducting circuits", ''Nature'' '''481''', 170-172 (2012), {{DOI|10.1038/nature10713}}</ref> [[Determinism#Quantum_mechanics_and_classical_physics|deterministic]] [[quantum teleportation]],<ref>L. Steffen, Y. Salathe, M. Oppliger, P. Kurpiers, M. Baur, C. Lang, C. Eichler, G. Puebla-Hellmann, A. Fedorov and A. Wallraff, "Deterministic quantum teleportation with feed-forward in a solid state system", ''Nature'' '''500''', 319-322 (2013), {{DOI|10.1038/nature12422}}</ref><ref name="NatGeo2013">{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/08/130814-physics-quantum-computing-teleportation-star-trek-qubit-science/ |title=Teleportation: Behind the Science of Quantum Computing |date=2013-08-14 |accessdate=2017-07-06}}</ref> and the [[Hong-Ou-Mandel effect]].<ref>C. Lang, C. Eichler, L. Steffen, J. M. Fink, M. J. Woolley, A. Blais, and A. Wallraff, "Correlations, indistinguishability and entanglement in Hong–Ou–Mandel experiments at microwave frequencies", ''[[Nature Physics]]'' '''9''', 345-348 (2013), {{DOI|10.1038/nphys2612}}</ref> [[File:4 Qubit Chip, 10.1103.PhysRevX.5.021027 (A. Wallraff, 2015).png|thumb|A [[integrated circuit|chip]] with four superconducting [[transmon]] qubits made by Andreas Wallraff and colleagues. Two of the qubits were used in the experiment which led to the publication of [https://journals.aps.org/prx/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevX.5.021027 "Digital Quantum Simulation of Spin Models with Circuit Quantum Electrodynamics"] in [[Physical Review X]] in June 2015.|left]]
In general, his research is primarily focused on investigating [[circuit QED]] (cQED) systems and their applications in [[superconducting quantum computing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.qudev.ethz.ch/research%20topics |title=Research Topics |date= |accessdate=2017-06-22}}</ref> These include implementing [[quantum gates]], identifying and eliminating sources of [[quantum decoherence]] to extend [[Relaxation_(NMR)#T1 and T2|qubit lifetimes]], and creating [[Solid-state electronics|solid-state]] architectures in which [[quantum error correction]] is possible.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.qudev.ethz.ch/research_topics/quantum_information_processing |title=Quantum Information Processing |date= |accessdate=2017-06-22}}</ref> In addition, he conducts research into "hybrid quantum systems"; cQED systems interacting with [[Rydberg atoms]] and [[semiconductor]] [[quantum dots]] to combine "the long coherence times available in microscopic quantum systems with the strong interactions and integration available in solid state systems... [to allow] for strong interactions with control fields and thus fast manipulation of the [[quantum state]] of a system."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.qudev.ethz.ch/research_topics/hybrid_quantum_systems |title=Hybrid Quantum Systems |date= |accessdate=2017-06-22}}</ref> [[File:Double Quantum Dot, 10.1103.PhysRevX.7.011030 (A. Wallraff, 2017).png|thumb|"A gate-defined [[GaAs]] double [[quantum dot]] (DQD) and a frequency-tunable [[high impedance]] [[resonator]] realized using an array of [[superconducting quantum interference devices]]... [This] false-color optical micrograph of a representative device [indicates] the substrate (dark gray), the superconducting structures (light gray), the gold top gates (yellow) forming the DQD, and its source and drain leads and contacts (blue)."<ref>A. Stockklauser, P. Scarlino, J. V. Koski, S. Gasparinetti, C. K. Andersen, C. Reichl, W. Wegscheider, T. Ihn, K. Ensslin, and A. Wallraff, "Strong Coupling Cavity QED with Gate-Defined Double Quantum Dots Enabled by a High Impedance Resonator", ''Physical Review X'' '''7''', 011030 (2017), {{DOI|10.1103/PhysRevX.7.011030}}</ref>|right]]
== Positions and speaking engagements == Since January 2006, Wallraff has held a professorship position at ETH Zürich where he is the head of the Quantum Device Lab within the Laboratory for Solid State Physics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.solid.phys.ethz.ch/people/person-detail.html?persid=134453 |title=Wallraff, Andreas, Prof. Dr. |date= |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> He has been awarded several grants, including two from the [[European Research Council]] (one in 2009 for hybrid [[cavity quantum electrodynamics]] and one in 2013 for superconducting [[quantum networks]])<ref>{{cite web|url=https://erc.europa.eu/projects-figures/erc-funded-projects/results?search_api_views_fulltext=andreas+wallraff |title=ERC Funded Projects |date= |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> and holds positions as the President of the Strategy Commission for the Department of Physics and Deputy Head of the Laboratory for Solid State Physics at ETH Zürich.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.phys.ethz.ch/the-department/management.html |title=Department Management and Administration |date= |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bi.id.ethz.ch/personensuche/personenDetail.view?page=1&lang=en&schnellSuche=andreas+wallraff&order=NAME&descending=false&paging=true&pid=20d35 |title=Andreas Wallraff |date= |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> He is also a member of the Scientific Committee for the [[Swiss National Science Foundation]] National Center of Competence in Research (NCCR) in Quantum Science and Technology (QSIT),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snf.ch/SiteCollectionDocuments/nfs/nccr_guide_2017.pdf |title=National Centres of Competence in Research |page=52 |date= |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> a member of the Global Future Council for the Future of Computing at the [[World Economic Forum]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.weforum.org/communities/the-future-of-computing |title=The Future of Computing |date= |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> and an Associate Fellow of the [[Canadian Institute for Advanced Research]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cifar.ca/profiles/andreas-wallraff/ |title=CIFAR |date= |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref>
Wallraff has been an invited speaker at several talks and conferences, including at the inaugural celebration for the Center for Quantum Coherence Science at the [[University of California, Berkeley]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://live-cqcs.pantheon.berkeley.edu/fiqcs/program/ |title=Center for Quantum Coherent Science |date=2017-01-09 |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> [[The Optical Society]] "Quantum Information and Measurement - Quantum Technologies" meeting at the [[Pierre and Marie Curie University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.osa.org/en-us/meetings/topical_meetings/quantum_information_and_measurement_(qim)_-_iv_qu/invited_speakers/ |title=OSA Quantum Information and Measurement |date= |accessdate=2017-06-20}}</ref> the IWQD 2017 workshop at the [[National Institute of Informatics]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.hiroshima-u.ac.jp/mhirokaw/iwqd/iwqd2017/program.html |title=IWQD 2017 |date= |accessdate=2017-06-20}}</ref> and the 635th WE [[Heraeus]] Seminar<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.zurich.ibm.com/heraeus/program_tues.html |title=IBM 635th WE-Heraeus Seminar |date=2017-01-31 |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> in 2017. In 2016 he spoke at the [[Institute of Physics]] Silicon Quantum Information Processing meeting at [[Murray Edwards College, Cambridge]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://siqip2016.iopconfs.org/speakers |title=IOP Silicon Quantum Information Processing 2016 |date=2017-01-31 |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> the [[University of Science and Technology of China]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://quantum.ustc.edu.cn/icqft/uploads/ICQFT2016_Program6.pdf |title=The International Conference on Quantum Foundation and Technology |date=2016-11-16 |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> and the SCALEQIT International Conference at the [[Delft University of Technology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chalmers.se/SiteCollectionDocuments/Mikroteknologi%20och%20Nanovetenskap/ScaleQIT.pdf |title=Delft SCALEQIT 2016 |date= |accessdate=2017-06-20}}</ref>
In previous years he also spoke at the [[University of Oxford]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.ox.ac.uk/qisw2012/program.html |title=QISW 2012 Workshop Program |date=2012-03-30 |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> the [[Max Planck Institute for the Science of Light]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mpl.mpg.de/en/institute/news/news/article/mpl-distinguished-lecturer-series-prof-andreas-wallraff.html |title=MPL Distinguished Lecturer Series |date=2014-05-08 |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> the Institute for Theoretical Atomic Molecular and Optical Physics (ITAMP) 2015 workshop at [[Harvard University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cfa.harvard.edu/itamp-event/light-matter-interactions-low-dimensions |title=Light Matter Interactions in Low Dimensions |date=2015-06-29 |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> and the [[Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics]] at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.kitp.ucsb.edu/online/denselight_c15/ |title=Non-equilibrium Dynamics of Strongly Interacting Photons |date=2015-10-07 |accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref>
